title: (x) Basic square "Rockstar Games" - custom drawn {Ray Larabie}
content:
I’ll love you eternally if you do.

[http://img248.imageshack.us/img248/2333/rstextdi3.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/img248.imageshack.us/img248/2333/rstextdi3.jpg "http://img248.imageshack.us/img248/2333/rstextdi3.jpg")

Closest I could find, but not correct: [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/flyfonts/cubist](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/flyfonts/cubist "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/flyfonts/cubist")  
the M is a bit off.

Thanks in advance.

 [‹ (x) 'Field Notes' geometric sans on notebook - Futura {Marten Fischer}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36543 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Faceted OCR-type font w/ serifs - CAD Beta {Angel} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/www.typophile.com/node/36525 "Go to next forum topic")
author: willy123

comments.content: Post the image here and I might be able to help, I can’t see it at Imageshack.

It is also similar to Pastelaria, a font by Eduardo Recife, but the G is different.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/rockstar_5848.gif)
Thanks, but it’s still not exactly the same. Any other candidates?

I assume it’s from one of the Grand Theft Auto games? Looks like it’s designed to resemble text output by the Vectrex or similar

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vectrex](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vectrex "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vectrex")

It’s so simple (only the M looks to diverge from the 2 x 2 grid, and that appears to be 3 x 2) that it might be easiest to just draw it... But on closer inspection many of the strokes fall short of baselines and caplines, perhaps to make it look a little more amateurish?

Just found DMTR.ORG’s O Geena, which is another variation on the theme:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/dimitrelima/geena/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/dimitrelima/geena/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/dimitrelima/geena/")
Darn, that’s pretty close. Too bad for the G.
It’s still not what I’m looking for though.

This reminds me of Patric King’s [Smile](http://web.archive.org/web/20080430223820/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/pretty/smile/) font. It has a sort of blur at the corners, especially in the light weights, that feels a lot like your sample. The M is the only structurally different letter at first glance. Squooshing (TM) would make the resemblance quite close.

- Mike Yanega
I believe the glow is an effect, so don’t mind that.

Yes, and I thought with the glow effect and the font’s thicker corners the effect would be enhanced. In any case, doesn’t it seem likely that this was a custom font? This straight line sort of lettering requires virtually no skill to create, as evidenced by the number of them found on free download sites.

- Mike Yanega
Yeah, but I can’t find the exact font anywhere.
I drew that in Deluxe Paint . . . really.

Well Ray, if you did it, that’s the end of that quest. Thanks for jumping in.

- Mike Yanega
But why can no one give me a name? I can draw this in Powerpoint. I know it’s a ridiculously simple font. But a name is needed. :’(
This is _not a font_. As Ray Larabie said above, he “drew that in Deluxe Paint.” Only these characters were specifically drawn — nothing else, nothing more. _There is no font._
Ray, you serious you used Deluxe Paint (presumably on an Amiga?) to get that mid 80s feel? That is attention to detail!
